FacilityName: Micronutrients, Div of Heritage Technologies, LLC.

_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: All Other Basic Inorganic Chemical Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary



Micronutrients

1550 Research Way

Indianapolis, Indiana 46231









Facility Description: 

 

Micronutrients, a Division of Heritage Technologies LLC (Micronutrients) is located at 1550 Research Way, in Indianapolis, Marion County Indiana.  Micronutrients operates under NAICS Code 325188, SIC Code 2819, Dun & Bradstreet Number 049714657, and Taxpayer ID number 35-1972203.    



Although Micronutrients primary business is the manufacture of feedstock supplements (zinc, copper, manganese special blends), etchants used in the printed circuit board industry, agricultural fertilizers, and specialty chemicals are produced for various clients.  



Micronutrients is dedicated to environmentally sustainable production.  Our patented and proprietary process maximizes the re-use concept of environmental compliance through adaptive uses of current chemical engineering technology.  Micronutrients purchases copper bearing acidic and alkaline etchants from the printed circuit board industry.  This material would otherwise be required to be managed as hazardous waste.  This material is then used in the production of IntelliBond C. The ingredients utilized in Micronutrients feedstock preparation include a proprietary blend of chemicals.  





Regulated Substances:



Anhydrous ammonia is the only ingredient with the potential to cause significant offsite consequences.  Micronutrients anhydrous ammonia tank is stored above ground, and has a 54,000 lb. capacity.  



  

Release Scenarios:  



RMP*Comp was utilized to conduct offsite consequences analysis.  The worst case scenario identified was the failure of the anhydrous ammonia tank.  



Worst Case Scenario



Estimated Distance to Toxic Endpoint:    2.6 miles (4.2 kilometers)

Threat type:    Toxic Gas

Physical State:    Liquefied under pressure

Quantity Released:    54,000 lbs.

Release Duration:    10 Minutes

Release Rate:    5,400 lbs. per Minute

Toxic Endpoint:    0.14 mg/L

Assumptions:    Wind Speed - 1.5 M / sec

ond (3.4 mph)

Stability Class: - F

Air Temperature: - 77 F (25 C)

  





The alternative scenario utilized was the rupture of one of the transfer hoses.



Alternative Scenario



Estimated Distance to Toxic Endpoint:    0.2 miles (0.3 Kilometers)

Threat type:    Toxic Gas

Physical State:    Liquefied under pressure

Quantity Released:    1,600 lbs.

Release Duration:    4 Minutes

Release Rate:    400 lbs. per Minute

Toxic Endpoint:    0.14 mg/L

Assumptions:    Wind Speed - 3 M / second (6.7 mph)

Stability Class: - D

Air Temperature: - 77 F (25 C)





Release Prevention Activities:



Micronutrients has a strong commitment to environmental health and safety and has active preventative maintenance and employee involvement programs.  Micronutrients primarily relies on engineering controls to mitigate potential safety hazards related to the anhydrous ammonia system.  Examples of the engineering controls include relief systems, check valves, scrubbers, manual and automatic shutoffs, interlocks, excess flow valves, and process area detectors.  Administrative controls such as the use of equipment inspections, an active incident investigation program, training program, and audits of safety and operational procedures are present and routinely conducted.  Information concerning our environmental health and safety programs is communicated to employees, customers, and the surrounding community via our website, meetings and management system programs.





Five Year Accident History:



Micronutrients maintains records of all incidents that occur at the facility.  To date, Micronutrients has not had a release of anhydrous ammonia off-site.  





Emergency Response Program:



Micronutrients maintains a Comprehensive Emergency Response Plan (CERP), which is reviewed annually.  Employees are trained annually in the contents of the CERP.  Evacuation drills are conducted on an as needed basis.   



 

Facility Response and Prevention Policies:



Micronutrients management system programs tha

t relate directly to accidental release prevention and chemical safety include; process safety information , process hazard analysis, standard operating procedures specific to process equipment, training, management of change, compliance audits, incident investigations, hot work permit, and contractor safety programs.  



In addition to onsite accident prevention procedures, Micronutrients' maintains relationships with local fire and emergency response personnel.  





Safety Improvement Plans:



Planned efforts to strength Micronutrients safety program include reviews of existing policies in accordance with our ISO certification procedures, and a commitment to consistent improvement of our programs.
